Aspirin and wintergreen are both metabolized as salicylic acid. You know what this is also used for? ..Salicylic acid is a keratolytic (peeling agent) that causes shedding of the outer layer of skin. Salicylic acid topical (for the skin) is used in the treatment of acne, dandruff, seborrhea, or psoriasis, and to remove corns, calluses, and warts.

But wait, there's more.

Salicylates and their derivatives have been used in sunscreen formulations. The aromatic benzene ring in the salicylate converts ultraviolet radiation into longer wave radiation that is felt as heat.

To make your mints there is an easier way. I'm the lab I work in, one of the things we do is to make pills to see how the medicin is released. I would have dried your wintergreen; added it to lactose powered and compressed it into a pill. You can get some press with pill moulds to make your pills.

It seems safer to me to just heat 95mls methanol to 65 Celsius, add pure crystals of acetylsalicyclic acid, start reflux and begin the addition of sulfuric acid while reflux is maintained for 1h and 5 minutes. Then add the hot methanol to cold water. It seems to me the most hazardous part of this one pot synthesis is the accelerated evaporation of methanol. I would rather personally avoid that step. the decresed amount of methanol shouldn't effect the results of the reaction since the methanol will be more saturated with the acetylsalicyclic acid while the reaction is occurring. This method would also save time as a lengthy step could be omitted. I am by no means a master of chemistry but I hypothesize that this small alteration would make the synthesis much safer. -Best wishes

In my opinion, wintergreen is best balanced with one of three flavors in hard candies: 1. Vanilla, 2. Black Pepper Extract, or 3. Juniper.  Vanilla is the best for simple, creamy hard candies or nougats.  Black Pepper is best for breath mints.  Juniper is the most complex, and really serves to make the candy a powerful flavor in its own right...the kind of thing to eat when it's the middle of the day and you just want a nice flavor.  Wintergreen can also be added to a simple caramel base and used to flavor vanilla pudding to end up with a vibrant root beer float flavored pudding.

So I did this synthesis pretty close to the video and here are just a few notes, tips and questions in no particular order:

1: You don't actually have to crush the aspirin. I started with 50g of whole 325mg tablets and they dissolved completely within 10 minutes of stirring in a 1L beaker. (aside from the insolubles)

2: At least for my aspirin, the binders were so fine that a coffee filter completely clogged. I could have put the filter back in a beaker, washed it and mixed it again, but I figured I had enough.

3: I used an addition funnel to add the sulfuric acid. It took more time, but not more of my time.

4: Methanol doesnt grow on trees where I live so instead of evaporating it, I distilled it. I think the point is to get rid of it as quickly as possible because as the methanol concentration drops, the equilibrium shifts away from the wintergreen.

5: Any suggestions here for how to sequester the water during the reflux? The only thing I had was magnesium sulfate and I wasn't sure what the magnesium was going to do as it can form magnesium salicylate so I didn't try it.

6: I'm not sure ice cold water is the best for the separation funnel. I had a lot of stuff crash out at the same time as the wintergreen and it formed noodly clumps that I think probably stuck to the wintergreen. The precipitate also clogged the separation funnel completely and stuck to the sides, making it impossible to see what was being poured. I had to disassemble it to clean it between washings.

7: Is there a reason we can't use something to neutralize the sulfuric acid in the reaction flask while its still hot before removing the methanol? You could stop he catalytic reaction then and not have to worry about loss of product during the distillation/evaporation phase.

8: My separation funnel doesn't have a small drip tube inside the ground glass tube and a lot of wintergreen just gooped to the side of it. I think the addition funnel, while not designed for separating, would have done a much better job at not losing product because of the drip tube.

For anyone curious, my H2SO4 was from "liquid fire" drain cleaner (distilled) and my methanol was from de-icing windshield wiper fluid. There ended up being about 1.2L methanol from a $4, 1gal jug. Cheap, but time consuming to fractionally distill. Industrially, methanol isn't an oil fraction or produced from biological sources. Its produced on its own from hydrating CO, so it really was pretty pure. No acetone or ethanol or other nonsense in it.

Wintergreen isn't really mint though. The term actually refers to plants that stay green the whole year. Another term used is also "evergreens". And plants from this family are often used to create methyl alcohols, also called wood alcohols. It's true that it resembles mint by taste and smell, but it's a whole another family of plants. True mints instead belong to the mint family (Lamiaceae). And actual mint flavoring is menthol. Methyl Salicylate is mint-like. Which is not the same thing.

To make these candies superb, I recommend mixing about 5 milliliters of creme de vanille liqueur, and roughly the same amount of liquefied extra virgin coconut oil (maybe...95 F or 35 C) into the big blob before cutting them out and leaving them not to fully harden, but just for a few hours to make them soft and somewhat chewy.  The same rough recipe can be used with meringue and   powdered sugar instead of the sodium alginate gum base for an airy crisp texture that also allows you to stretch the flavors out more.  Wintergreen is personally my favorite single sweet flavor in the world, and I have done many things with wintergreen extracts and flavorings.  I even made homemade wintergreen ice cream (which is pretty good, if a bit weak) and wintergreen pudding (which doesn't really work very well...wintergreen is just not a strong enough flavor for pudding).  Wintergreen also pairs very well with true cinnamon (cinnamomum zeylanicum/verum), and the combination makes for an excellent flavor base for homemade marshmallows.  The marshmallows are best on their own, but do combine well with crushed pistachios and cream as a sort of pseudo-mousse.  It should also be noted that wintergreen adds excellent flavor balance to hard candies flavored with mastic, lavender, or rose.

The important difference between food grade and reagent grade isn't the quantity of impurities, it's the type/safety of the impurities. Food grade means the impurities are safe enough to eat. Reagent grade typically has less impurities, but the impurities are considered for their ability to interfere with typical reactions for a given chemical, not safety.

I'm no expert, so do your own research to determine which chemicals to use.

Don't mistakenly assume that more pure = safer.

Some ideas :
1)Boiling down the methanol got the reaction going again and since methanol was removed, the equilibrium was shifted to the left. Removing it under vacuum without extra heat would have stopped the reaction from running again...
2) You should have bought food grade salicylic acid, it would prevent that pink color from occurring, plus it's free of any binders, etc. It would also be converted to methyl salicylate in one single step, thus decreasing the amount of methanol needed and increasing the yield. Plus, it's probably cheaper than using aspirin pills.
